hand.section:
To my L. T
re
r June 1 1592

page.lettertext:
fol.203r
Belgia A 1592 pr
o
Junij To my Lord Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. The 24 day of May w
t
in a daies jorney
of
Steenwicke
, I receaved her
Ma
ties
l
res
to the
General states
, and
to my self, w
t
one from yo
r
L. w
ch
were dated the 8 and the 9 of
the same. Advertised thereby of the pleasure of her Hig
nes
,
that I should deale w
t
the
Councel
, and
Count Maurice
, aswell
as w
t
the states, for sending further succors to the service of the
Kinge
, I parted presently upon it, and came the same day, where
the Count was encamped. Having signified there unto him
her Ma
ties
desire, and used requisit persuasion, to move him to ad-
vance it, he made me this answear,
at he was very well
assured of the states resolution, not to send for this present
any more into
France
: for
at the Countrey had assented to a
large contribution, for the atcheiving heere of those attemptes,
w
ch
are determined this sommer: w
ch
also tende to the assuring
of the Province of
Frise
, and that their hono
r
was engaged in
the enterprise of Steenwicke. Wherupon for himself, as it wa
[s]
not a matter,
at belonged unto him, but to the states of the
contrey, so he thought it very hard to be pressed therunto,
not willing to intermeddle ether one way or other. And as
touching the troupes, w
ch
her Ma
tie
required of her owne interte
[n]
ment, he was fully persuaded,
at assoone as they were gone,
e
states would revoke their forces out of France: and
at besides
it would occasion a great discontentment among the people of
these Provinces, and cause that nothing wold be done ether heere
or in France: w
ch
would prejudice exceedingly both her
Ma
tie
and them. This was the substance of his answear unto
me: Wherunto I replied,
at howsoever the states had already
resolved, to imploie there forces heere at home, both her Ma
tie
and they had but onely one designe, w
ch
was to ruine the Enemi
e
by all the meanes they could devise. And seing in all appar
a
ce
he was already reduced to suche termes of extremitie, as an
opportunitie nowe served, to precipitat all his power, and that
very shortly, by assisting the Kinge w
t
suche strength as they
were able, they could not answear in reason to their friendes
and allies, for their wilfull neglect of a notable advantage. And
fol.203v
to that w
ch
he objected that they had levied a subsidie, in regard of
their owne estate, and were nowe in suche an action, as they
could not well give over, w
t
the credit of the contrey, or the
peoples satisfaction, it importing the deliverance of a principal
Province, from subjection of the Enemie, her Ma
tie
in her l
re
had made sufficient answear, That if the Enemie in France
prevaile of his designe, his losses heere at home of a fewe
little townes will soone be recovered. And for contenting of
the people, w
ch
cannot happely conceave, how the expending
of their mony, to support a forraine prince, can redounde
unto the contrey muche more beneficiall, then it may doe
heere among themselves, in these intended exploites, w
ch
are
done before there eies, are understoode of them all and carie
a kinde of certaintie of that successe that they desire, That
I signified was a point, in w
ch
his owne good endevo
r
, w
t
the
rest of the Gouverno
rs
, and those that have the maneging
of the affaires of their state, was specially required, For if
they would resolve to concurre in some good forme of a publicke
Remonstrance, and travel in suche sorte, as they were able w
th
the people, it would undoubtedly prove easie, to compasse their
good liking. But howsoever they weare inclined, for w
t
holding
of their owne forces, her Ma
tie
did expect, that they would not
refuse her, for the enseignes demanded of the Englishe assistanc
e
For they might drawe out of
Holland
, for a present supplie, as
good as 15 companies of their owne pay, w
ch
were [reseaved] heere
behinde, for defense against the Enemie, while the armie is at
Steenwicke. They have also lately intertened as I writte
unto yo
r
L.
e 17 f the last, 2000 men of
Juliers
, to be
imploied in their service upon certaine weekes warning: so as
nothing can impeache, but
at the intention of her Ma
tie
for
e
use of those
at she requireth, should be willingly accorded. There
was nothing saide to this that was greatly material, nor to
divers other pointes, that I proposed to like effect. But he
concluded all his answear,
at for his owne particular, he would
nether make noe marre the mater, but leave it to the states.
fol.204r
To the self same purpose, as I had deal
t
ed
w
t
the Count, I dealt
the next day after w
t
the Councel of state: who thought the
motion out of season, their campe being setled in the siege of
Steenwicke: the taking wherof would free
e land of Frise
of a great Contribution amounting yerly at
e lest, to 24000
li
sterling, w
ch
is paied to the Enemie by the frontier inhabi-
tants: for w
ch
they thought it impossible to gette the states
to yeld unto it. They
also
urged therew
t
all
at the
affaires of the King did alter very muche, and were nowe in
an other state, then at the time of the date of her Ma
ties
l
re
.
For they had letters from sondrie places,
at
Parma
was re-
turned, and in all probablitie, would give some onsette at
his co
m
ing. And where her Hig
nes
did require 2000 of her
owne subjects, to be shipped out of hand, they stoode upon
the Contract, that they could
not
in equitie be otherwise disposed
then the contrey shall appoint: for
at her Ma
tie
hath cauti
o
[ed]
for the answearing of her charges. In conclusion they tooke it
for a matter appertening to
e
states,
of the contrey
and so
remitted me to them. As I had formerly replied to the
Countes allegations, I delivered the same to the Councel againe,
to witte in suche pointes, as their speeches agreed; and declared
besides to their further objections, that they knewe well enough
they were able for a time, to spare of good power to
e assisting
of the King, and yet retaine sufficient strength, for defense
of all their places. And as for
at w
ch
they had pleaded upon
the mater of remboursement, it was not greatly pertinent.
For in a manifest case, of suche advantage to the cause, they
should deale very strictly w
t
her Ma
tie
if having suffered
those of Holland to send certaine Regiments into France,
w
t
out asking the advise of the rest of the Provinces, they
would sticke at her demaund w
ch
is so orderly imparted
and desired at their handes. Againe albeit they were
unwilling to take any order in this mater, but putte me over
to the states, they were not ignorant notw
t
standing,
at the
fol.204v
states intermedling in a cause of this q
alitie
was a flatte usurpation
and that all the actions of these warres, by graunt of the Contract,
were belonging onely to her Ma
tie
and to the Colledge of the Councel
wherby her Highnes had autoritie, as muche as all the Councel, to
appoint the imploiment of their forces for
e service of the Contrey.
I wished them at last that although they would not send any more
of their owne, they should not stand w
t
her Ma
tie
for the 14 English
bandes, w
ch
if they would not permitte to be presently sent being most
of them there, and engaged in the siege, yet because it was hoped
that in 10 daies after,
e service would be ended, and because they
had besides them, sufficient forces of the Contrey, to perfourme
the rest that they intended, for
e attemptes of this sommer, they
should not make any further question, when Steenwicke was re
duced. To w
ch
effect I did desire, that they would falle in consul
tation, and give the states their best advise. But to that they
would not answear. I had this conference w
t
the Councel the
25 of May, in the Campe before Steenwicke. But because they
left me to the states, to whome her Ma
ties
l
re
was addressed express
ly, and were residing at the Hage, I came hither therupon w
t
all
possible speede: where I found their assemblie dissolved for a time,
and divers of the Deputies departed home into their Provinces,
so as those
at were remaining, made some doubt of breaking open
her Ma
ties
letter, for want of their being in competent number.
But when I had declared to some in particular, that this Recesse
of the states, at suche a time as the Contrey had greatest neede
of their service, would seeme a practise for the nones, to defeate
her Hig
nes
of her purpose, and
at I thought she would goe forward,
w
t
out attending their meeting, they assembled then as many as
were abiding heere in place, and used divers communciations and
comminges too and fro, to debate the mater w
t
me: w
ch
was all to
one effect, wth
e speeches of the Count, and Councel of Estate.
But this they added more,
at for their levies in Juliers, they were
for that provision, w
ch
they made for
Britaine,
and not to be
imploied in any other part: for w
ch
also their shippes, w
ch
they promised
for their portion are in a readines: so as nowe they doe attend w
at
her
Hig
nes
will resolve. Moreover for the companies in Holland, w
ch
I
alleaged they might use in lieu of the Englishe, they had freshe intelligence
fol.205r
Belgia B 1592 pri
o
Junij to my L Trea
s
out of
Brabant
,
at
Mondragon
was in feeld w
t
1500 footemen, and
towardes 400 horse and had taken
Sgravenwesel
, w
ch
was a
place of good strength appertening to these Contreis. From thens
as it seemeth he marcheth towardes
Tourne
hoult
hoult
and
Westelo
, w
ch
are also castels in one possession: and as his forces shall augme
[nt]
as by report they doe daily, they feare some greater mater. For
prevention whereof they might not suffer those troupes to be
sent out of Holland. Lastly they told me,
at they had newly
given leave to their Coronels in France, who they thought at
this present had scarce in all 1000 men, to raise their numbers
to two thousand foure hundred: w
ch
they were in
good
hope woulde
satisfie the Kinge, considering their estate: as they doubted not
also, but her Ma
tie
would be moved not to presse them any more
upon notice of as muche, as they had declared, w
ch
they praied
me to certefie. For as yet they were uncertaine, w
h
ether in a
mater of that consequence, being fewer then they should be, and therefore
not autorised to assemble as a college, they might answear her Ma
tie
by way of a letter: w
ch
yet they meant to putte againe in further
deliberation. I am borne in hand by
M
r
Buzenval
,
at he hath dealt
very earnestly, to helpe this mater forward, being so commanded by
the Kinge: but hath had no other answear then that w
ch
I have signi-
fied. To give yo
r
L. some notice of my privat persuasion, If her
Ma
tie
at first, as she requested them to yeeld some greater aide
unto the King had required therew
t
all in absolut manner,
at
e 14
Englishe bandes should be presently embarked, I thinke they had not
made any great opposition, and I am sure it had impeached the
composing of their Campe, wherby there had bin hope,
at in
e ende
they would have spared some enseignes of their owne. More over
I hold it my duty to certefie yo
r
L. that where her Ma
tie
doth account
that the 14 foote companies should make 2000 men they will not
reache to
at number in common conjecture, by seven or eight
hundred at the lest. For there are almost 300 comprehended in
the allowance of the dead paies, and of suche persons in every
company as never come to service. It is also supposed
at their
other defectes, for want of renforcement out of
England
, and by
fol.205v
divers
other accidents, and their losses in this siege, together w
t
the numbers that
will runne from their captaines before they come to be embarked will
stretche in all likelihood, to twice as many more. For there were
slaine and hurt, before I parted from the Campe, not so fewe as a 100
Englishe: of w
ch
there were 60 in one day sent to
Campen
,
Horne
,
Enchusen
, and
Amsterdame
. And no doubt they have decreased conti-
nually sins, and will doe more and more as they come to harder servce
in assaulting or otherwise. Upon this weaknes of the Companies both
the states and the Councel did earnestly insist
at being drawen away
from hens, they should be forced out of hand to dissolve their armie,
e
king should receave, but a smalle relief of men, and at last by that
meanes nothing would be done of the one side or the other. Because
I doe presume,
at
S
r
Francis Vere
, and
S
r
Robert Sidney
will adve
r
tise
yo
r
L. of all that hath passed, sins their first sitting downe, I should
but overtrouble you w
t
my particular relation. There is very
good hope,
at we shall carie awaie the place: and we looke to un-
derstand it w
t
in foure or five daies. At my being there the
towne was blocked one every side, aproches made unto the counter-
scarffe and the most of their gabbions placed already. And by this
time I suppose, they have planted their artillerie: of w
ch
there were
47 great peeces, and a 11 of the felde: wherew
t
the purpose to
batten in 4 several places, for the making of two breaches. They
have also made a cavallier, upon w
ch
they appoint to place some
peeces of ordinance, for stouring the rampart
,
at the time of the
batterie
assault.
Besides they have sette certaine pioners a worke to sappe
the walles, and divers ingeno
rs
to devise artificial fires, and are de-
termined to putte all in execution in one day, for
e more astonishment
of the Enemie. The towne is very litle, and w
at
garrison is in
it we can not conjecture. For they have carried themselves very
souldierlike, and having made many sallies, never left us a prisoner
by whome we might learne the state of the towne. S
r
Francis
Vere hath bin shotte w
t
a harquebuze in
e smalle of his left legge
and his brother
Horace Vere
in one of his armes: but I hope they
will bothe recover it quickly. The hindrance of that w
ch
was intended
at Enchusen, proceeded of the Enemie, who not fullie contented w
t
fol.206r
the persone alone of the principal party, that was continuer of the
practise, required him to bring some other pledges besides, and more
then could be well perfourmed, but w
t
losse of longer time, then
could conveniently be spared before
e siege of Steenwicke. But
the partie doth yet continue in
e handes of
e Enemie, and his
pollicie undiscovered. In the
Marchants
busines, w
ch
her Ma
tie
recommendeth, I have travellled as muche as is possible for me
and I thinke they doe rest indifferently well pleased. The
decision of certaine pointes was differred by the states w
t
e
companies good liking, to the end of certaine monethes, w
ch
when
they be resumed I will helpe to end to their content.
And so
beseeching yo
r
L. to acquaint her Ma
tie
w
t
my dealinges, I take
my humble leave. Hage June 1 1592.
